head.title: Power Authority Unveils Pair Of 100-Foot Wind Turbines

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Power Authority Unveils Pair Of 100-Foot Wind Turbines

abstract.p: Long Island Power Authority chairman Richard Kessel, in ceremony at Shoreham nuclear power plant, dedicates two wind turbines that will supply power to Long Island (S)

block.p: In a ceremony held Tuesday at the site of the defunct Shoreham nuclear power plant, Richard M. Kessel dedicated two wind turbines that will supply power to Long Island, something the 809-megawatt Shoreham reactor never did.

''We stand in the shadow of a modern-day Stonehenge, a multibillion-dollar monument to a failed energy policy, to formally commission the operation of a renewable energy technology that will harness the power of the wind for the benefit of Long Island's environment,'' said Mr. Kessel, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority.

In a ceremony held Tuesday at the site of the defunct Shoreham nuclear power plant, Richard M. Kessel dedicated two wind turbines that will supply power to Long Island, something the 809-megawatt Shoreham reactor never did.

''We stand in the shadow of a modern-day Stonehenge, a multibillion-dollar monument to a failed energy policy, to formally commission the operation of a renewable energy technology that will harness the power of the wind for the benefit of Long Island's environment,'' said Mr. Kessel, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority.
He was joined by past and present LIPA trustees, elected officials, environmentalists and some of the original anti-Shoreham protesters.

The two 100-foot turbines, each with 25-foot blades, can generate a combined 100 kilowatts of power under optimum wind conditions. The authority said the turbines, constructed on a 47-acre site next to the former nuclear plant, cost $500,000 and would produce enough electricity to power about 25 homes a day.
